abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: The impacts of climate change are and will continue to be far-reaching, and environmental justice communities are disproportionately impacted due to environmental racism and related forms of oppression. Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education encourages that the connection between science and society be explicitly taught in science classrooms. Here, I describe a fictional case study where students decide how to allocate a budget at a non-profit organization tasked with mitigating environmental issues in a town that contains environmental justice communities. Students are each assigned a role in the community and must reach a consensus on their budget in small groups before the whole class votes on a consensus budget. Afterward, students perform a metacognitive activity that encourages them to reflect on the human health impacts of their decisions and how their role impacted their decision-making process. Quantitative and qualitative feedback from students shows that by the end of the course, students appreciate the importance of science literacy in understanding global issues and that they are able to connect environmental justice to their lives and coursework. This case study helps fill an unmet need in climate change education by allowing students to practice empathy in topics related to climate change and environmental justice.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Many non-biology majors are required to take a science course as part of a core curriculum, and engaging this group of students can be challenging, especially with worsening attitudes toward science by students (1). One solution for improving this attitude suggested by Vision and Change is to develop curricula with explicit connections drawn between science and society (2). This includes equipping students with the ability to understand global issues as well as understanding the societal context in which science is done. By increasing a student’s sense of connectedness to course material, they could have better attitudes toward biology, would be better informed on global issues, and would be better citizens (3). Climate change is one of the most pressing global issues, and climate anxiety is negatively impacting the mental health of young people, making this topic particularly relevant to undergraduates (4, 5). While climate change affects us all, the impacts of climate change are disproportionately felt by marginalized groups. Environmental racism describes how some communities have been targeted to experience a disproportionate amount of pollution and environmental hazards via racist environmental policies. Environmental justice is a response to environmental racism and other forms of environmental inequities and is described by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as “the fair treatment and meaningful involvement of all people regardless of race, color, national origin, or income, with respect to the development, implementation, and enforcement of environmental laws, regulations, and policies” (6). In other words, environmental justice aims to ameliorate the disparities experienced by marginalized groups, which in the context of environmental justice are called environmental justice communities (Table 1). Environmental justice communities are exposed to several environmental hazards including the urban heat island effect, which is the result of racist redlining policies in the United States and leads to an increased risk of heat-related illness (7), and drinking water contamination by PFAS (per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances) and microplastics pollution. These environmental hazards will be exacerbated by climate change. Urban heat islands are directly tied to global warming (8), water contamination is predicted to worsen as extreme weather and changes in the water cycle increase the introduction of toxins into the water supply (9, 10), and plastics contribute to climate change through lifecycle emissions (11) and water and food chain pollution through microplastics (12, 13). Here, I used environmental racism and environmental justice as a connecting point between students’ lives, global challenges, and human biology.

tr.th: Connection to climate change and/or human health

tr.td: Environmental racism
The intentional or inadvertent oppression of individuals or communities through racist environmental policies.
Environmental racism makes it such that communities of color disproportionately experience the effects of climate change which leads to increased mortality in these communities.
Environmental justice
A response to ameliorate the effects of environmental racism and other inequities in environmental policy, including inequities stemming from social class.
Environmental justice practices can lead to the improvement of health for individuals experiencing environmental racism and related forms of oppression.
Environmental justice communities
Groups that have experienced inequities due to environmental policy.
These groups are more likely to be exposed to environmental hazards which negatively impact human health.
Urban heat island effect
Describes how building materials that are used in urban areas absorb more heat leading to greater air temperatures (1°C–4°C).
The urban heat island effect leads to increased risk of heat-related illness and is exacerbated by global warming.
PFAS
Chemicals found in a range of household products including flame retardants and non-stick pans.
PFAS are associated with immune deficits, cancers, and developmental issues. Increased extreme weather caused by climate change has increased the spread of PFAS from contaminated sites.
Microplastics
Small (~1 mm) particles formed from the shattering of plastics.
Microplastics have been implicated in hormonal dysfunction and cancer. Increased extreme weather caused by climate change has increased the escape of microplastics from dumps.

sec.p: To address the need for activities that allow for authentic engagement with issues related to climate change and environmental justice, I designed a fictional case study as a formative assessment for a semester-long exploration of environmental racism and environmental justice in my human biology lecture course. The learning objectives for this activity were for students to be able to:

list-item.p: Describe ways in which the environment impacts human health,
Develop their own perspectives on the relationships between government policies, race, and human health, and
Empathize with individuals who experience environmental racism and related injustices.

sec.p: The case study required students to allocate a hypothetical budget at a non-profit to help address environmental hazards related to the urban heat island effect and water contamination by PFAS and microplastics. These societal issues are relevant to all students and are already considered in EPA policy (6). One of the challenges with teaching about environmental justice is that each student has experienced environmental racism differently in their lives. To encourage students to develop empathy (14) and to promote student engagement in the activity (15), students were assigned roles within the fictional community to play throughout the activity. After the activity, students completed a reflection activity to reinforce learning and consider how their experience and the experience of the character they were playing influenced their decision-making. Feedback from students at the end of the course demonstrates that students valued science literacy as useful for understanding global issues and found environmental justice to be relevant to their lives and coursework. This case study activity helps fill a gap in pedagogical tools for teaching climate change and environmental justice.

sec.title: PROCEDURE
sec.p: The environmental justice case study described here was used as a formative assessment three-fourths through the semester of a 41-student human biology course for non-majors at Wellesley College after several class sessions relating to environmental justice and human physiology. Briefly, students were asked to role-play through a budgeting process where community members in a fictional town are tasked with allocating monies to resolve environmental hazards affecting both environmental justice communities and communities without this designation. Before the activity, students should be able to define environmental racism and environmental justice as well as describe the human health impacts of PFAS, microplastics, and the urban heat island effect (see Table 1 for an overview of these topics and Supplemental Material 1 for PowerPoint slides covering these topics). Prior to class, I provided a description of the activity to students (Supplemental Material 2) which includes a spreadsheet that describes a fictional town and its struggles with environmental hazards. This spreadsheet also includes a list of potential solutions to these hazards of varying impact and cost (see references in Supplemental Material 2 for more information about PFAS and microplastics). The total of these mitigation strategies is over $85 million but students were only allowed to spend a $25 million budget, so therefore, the challenge of the activity is prioritizing changes that will have the greatest impact on the community. Interventions were binned into three levels, from level 1 to level 3, based on total cost (with level 1 being the least expensive).

To start class, I reviewed the details of the case, highlighting which communities are environmental justice communities (see Table 2 for details of the lesson timeline and Supplemental Material 3 for slides to use in class for the activity). I also provided students with a list of discussion norms and guidelines so each student would be empowered to participate to their fullest capabilities (see Supplemental Material 4 for example norms). Students worked in four-person activity groups that had been consistently used throughout the semester, and each student was randomly assigned one of four fictional roles within the community: (i) a pregnant woman living near a firefighting training facility, (ii) an elderly resident living in a community with PFAS contamination, (iii) a fisherman living in an industrial area, or (iv) an individual living near an abandoned mall in a relatively affluent area. As described in the case study, some of these individuals are from historically redlined neighborhoods that are composed of communities of color. These hypothetical individuals would have experienced a range of injustices and have different health risk factors (e.g., a pregnant woman is more vulnerable to environmental toxins), and so the challenge for students is to empathize with individuals who may have experienced environmental hazards in a different way from themselves. Each group was asked to develop a $25 million budget however they saw fit with no limitations on the number of remedial strategies used from each category, keeping in mind the role they were playing. Students had approximately 20 minutes to discuss the remediation options and reach a consensus within their groups. Once a group reached a consensus, they submitted their budget by using a Google Form to vote for or against each remediation option. If a simple majority of groups voted for an option, that option was approved and added to the class budget. At the end of voting, I summed the total cost of approved options within the activity spreadsheet. Depending on the allocated budget at this stage, students proposed motions to add items (if they were underbudget) or remove items (if they were overbudget), and these motions were voted on via a simple majority. With my class of 41 students, there were four proposed motions, and I allotted 2–5 minutes for each motion for students to express opinions before voting. The final consensus-reaching step took approximately 20 minutes, and this process could be extended if desired.

sec.p: After the activity, I assigned students a metacognitive activity which included the following questions:

list-item.p: How did you decide which projects to fund? What factors were most important to you?
What were the human health ramifications for the projects you funded? What about the projects you didn’t fund?
What was challenging about playing your role? How did your role impact your way of thinking?

sec.p: This reflection helped to reinforce the empathy practice students had in discussion, gave students a chance to compare their own personal experiences with environmental racism to that of their assigned role, and encouraged students to consider how they made difficult decisions. The assignment should take about 30 minutes to complete and can be given as homework. I graded the assignment for effortful completion (at least 250 words) and provided brief feedback to students who demonstrated misconceptions about the definitions of some of the key terms. If time allows, this reflection can be followed by a group discussion in the following class where students share their responses.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: Students responded well to the activity (Exemption from Brandeis University Human Research Protection Program: IRB Protocol #24117R-E Peters). At the end of the semester, student responses to Likert scale survey questions showed that students valued the importance of biological literacy in understanding global issues (Fig. 1A); 37 of 40 students either agreed or strongly agreed with the statement, “I believe that biological literacy (understanding) is required for understanding important global issues.” Students also thought that course learning objectives associated with describing connections between the environment and human health (Fig. 1B, top) and developing their own perspectives on environmental justice issues (Fig. 1B, bottom) were extremely well met. Thirty-eight of 40 students thought the course learning objective, “Students will be able to describe ways in which the environment impacts human health,” was either well met or extremely well met, and 37 of 40 students thought the course learning objective, “Students will be able to develop their own perspectives on the relationships between government policies, race, and human health,” was either well met or extremely well met.

caption.p: Anonymous survey data from students. (A) At the end of the course, a majority of students agreed that biological literacy is important for understanding global issues (strongly agree = 24, agree = 13, neither agree nor disagree = 3, disagree = 0, strongly disagree = 0). (B) At the end of the course, a majority of students thought the course learning objective of, “Students will be able to describe ways in which the environment impacts human health,” was extremely well met (top; extremely well met = 24, well met = 14, somewhat met = 2, slightly met = 0, not at all met = 0). A majority of students also thought the course learning objective of, “Students will be able to develop their own perspectives on the relationship between government policies, race, and human health,” was extremely well met (top; extremely well met = 22, well met = 15, somewhat met = 3, slightly met = 0, not at all met = 0).

sec.p: Additionally, students performed a reflection activity at the end of the course (3 weeks after the case study activity) answering the following questions:

list-item.p: Over the break, someone may ask you what you learned in biology class. What one thing would you share with them?
In what ways were the concepts you learned in BISC 109 related to topics from other classes you’ve taken at Wellesley?

sec.p: A thematic analysis of the 82 answers to these questions (all 41 students responded to each of the questions) showed that 41 of the responses mentioned environmental justice or environmental racism, and that 31 of the 41 students mentioned one of these topics in at least one of their answers. Twenty-two responses discussed how these topics connect to their other coursework (Fig. 2, “Connectedness”), fourteen discussed how it was surprising or helpful to talk about these topics in a science course (Fig. 2, “Novel”), and nine discussed implications for human health (Fig. 2, “Human Health”). One limitation of this feedback is that it was collected 3 weeks after the case study activity; regardless, the feedback is suggestive of students responding well to a climate change and environmental justice curriculum. In sum, the described case study aligns well with the Vision and Change goal of increasing connectedness between students’ lives and their coursework. The topics in the fictional case study left a lasting and meaningful impact on students as measured by quantitative and qualitative student feedback.

caption.p: Thematic analysis of course metacognitive activity. Heat map showing the three most common themes from thematic analysis of two questions from an end-of-course metacognitive activity (n = 41 students and each student responded to both questions for a total of 82 answers). Forty-one of the 82 answers discussed environmental justice or environmental racism, and the 34 that belonged to at least one of the three most common themes are displayed (each column represents a student response). Of those, 22 discussed how the material connected to their other coursework, 14 discussed the novelty of the topic in a science course, and nine discussed implications for human health.
